qas.question: Who introduced the lute to Spain?

qas.question: Who brought the lute to France?
What court held singer-lutenists before the Norman conquest?
What store has floor painting dedicated to the lutenists?

context: Beside the introduction of the lute to Spain (<b8_0>Andalusia<b8_0/>) by <a0_0>the <b7_0><b9_0>Moors<b9_0/><b7_0/><a0_0/>, another important point of transfer of the lute from Arabian to European culture was <a1_0><b10_0>Sicily<b10_0/><a1_0/>, where it was brought either by <a2_0><b11_0>Byzantine or later by Muslim musicians<b11_0/><a2_0/>. There were singer-lutenists at the court in <a3_0><b12_0>Palermo<b12_0/><a3_0/> following the Norman conquest of the island from the Muslims, and the lute is depicted extensively in the ceiling paintings in the <a4_0><b13_0>Palermo’s royal Cappella Palatina<b13_0/>,<a4_0/> dedicated by the <b6_0>Norman King Roger II of Sicily<b6_0/> in 1140. His Hohenstaufen grandson <b5_0>Frederick II<b5_0/>, Holy Roman Emperor (1194 - 1250) continued integrating Muslims into his court, including Moorish musicians. By the 14th century, lutes had disseminated throughout Italy and, probably because of the cultural influence of the Hohenstaufen kings and emperor, based in Palermo, the lute had also made significant inroads into the German-speaking lands.
